articles.headline: Shell Delays Arctic Oil Drilling Until 2013
articles.snippet: A testing mishap further delayed the company’s six-year, $4.5 billion effort to drill off the coast of Alaska, although it will not stop preliminary work on several wells in the region this year.
articles.abstract: A testing mishap further delayed the company’s six-year, $4.5 billion effort to drill off the coast of Alaska, although it will not stop preliminary work on several wells in the region this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the prospect of rich new oil fields in tantalizing reach, Shell Oil announced on Monday that it was forced to put off completing wells in the Alaskan Arctic for another year after a spill containment dome was damaged during a testing accident.

articles.headline: All the TV News Since 2009, on One Web Site
articles.snippet: The Internet Archive plans to make more than 350,000 programs available on its Web site beginning Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The Internet Archive plans to make more than 350,000 programs available on its Web site beginning Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inspired by a pillar of antiquity, the Library of Alexandria, Brewster Kahle has a grand vision for the Internet Archive, the giant aggregator and digitizer of data, which he founded and leads.

articles.headline: In Video Clip, Romney Calls 47% ‘Dependent’ and Feeling Entitled
articles.snippet: A video of Mitt Romney at a fund-raiser shows him saying that those who pay no federal taxes would vote for President Obama “no matter what.”
articles.abstract: A video of Mitt Romney at a fund-raiser shows him saying that those who pay no federal taxes would vote for President Obama “no matter what.”
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Success of Crowdfunding Puts Pressure on Entrepreneurs
articles.snippet: Crowdfunding is a popular and lucrative source of money for entrepreneurs, but it is not always easy to turn a good idea into a profitable product.
articles.abstract: Crowdfunding is a popular and lucrative source of money for entrepreneurs, but it is not always easy to turn a good idea into a profitable product.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — An effort to build a sleek aluminum charging dock for the iPhone generated fervor online when it was announced last December. The project’s creators raised close to $1.5 million through Kickstarter, a crowdfunding Web site, and promised to start shipping their Elevation Dock in April to those who had backed the project.

articles.headline: Occupy Wall Street: A Frenzy That Fizzled
articles.snippet: The protests that began a year ago changed little, and were not much more than a fad that left a lasting chant: We are the 99 percent.
articles.abstract: The protests that began a year ago changed little, and were not much more than a fad that left a lasting chant: We are the 99 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: It will be an asterisk in the history books, if it gets a mention at all.

articles.headline: Israeli Diplomat Is Man in Middle
articles.snippet: Ambassador Michael B. Oren, who happens to have been born and bred in New Jersey, is representing a prime minister who has infuriated the White House.
articles.abstract: Ambassador Michael B. Oren, who happens to have been born and bred in New Jersey, is representing a prime minister who has infuriated the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel engaged in an unusually public dispute with the Obama administration over Iran, Mr. Netanyahu’s man in Washington, Michael B. Oren, has been working rooms all over town.

articles.headline: In Car Country, Obama Trumpets China Trade Case
articles.snippet: President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization. He announced the action in the industrial battleground of Ohio.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization. He announced the action in the industrial battleground of Ohio.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — In a vivid display of the powers of incumbency, President Obama on Monday filed a broad new trade case against China at the World Trade Organization, announcing the action in this industrial battleground where Mitt Romney has pressed his argument that the president has not done enough to protect American workers.

articles.headline: Romney Says Remarks on Voters Help Clarify Position
articles.snippet: Facing criticism for saying 47 percent of voters believe they are “victims,” Mitt Romney sought to steer the conversation toward a debate about government’s role in people’s lives.
articles.abstract: Facing criticism for saying 47 percent of voters believe they are “victims,” Mitt Romney sought to steer the conversation toward a debate about government’s role in people’s lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney on Tuesday fully embraced the substance of his secretly recorded comments that 47 percent of Americans are too dependent on government, saying that his views helped define the philosophical choice for voters in his campaign against President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Teachers End Chicago Strike on Second Try
articles.snippet: Union delegates endorsed a proposed contract, allowing 350,000 children to return to classes on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Union delegates endorsed a proposed contract, allowing 350,000 children to return to classes on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago Teachers Union agreed on Tuesday to end its strike in the nation’s third-largest school system, allowing 350,000 children to return to classes on Wednesday and bringing to a close, at least for now, a tense standoff over issues like teacher evaluations and job security that had upended this city for more than a week.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Steven Yaccino
